thread.title: Brandon LaFell gives himself an ‘F’ against Jets - Patriots
thread.title_full: Brandon LaFell gives himself an ‘F’ against Jets - Patriots

author: boston.com
title: Brandon LaFell gives himself an ‘F’ against Jets - Patriots
text:
Brandon LaFell isn’t his harshest critic, but he’s pretty close.
In the Patriots’ 30-23 win over the Jets on Sunday, LaFell finished the game with two catches, 25 yards, and six of New England’s 11 drops, via the AP .
“ If I had to give myself a grade , it’d be an ‘F,’ ” LaFell told reporters after the game. “ No excuses, man . I just let the ball get out of my hands too much.”
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below LaFell spent the first seven weeks of the Patriots season on the physically unable to perform list after suffering a foot injury during training camp. And he looked rusty against the Jets.
“I don’t think any of us really felt great about the way we performed today,” Bill Belichick said when asked about LaFell’s comments. “We can all do a better job, so I’m sure that everybody feels that way. I do, and I’m sure everybody else does. We just left too many plays on the field too often.”
It wasn’t all bad for the six-year veteran receiver in his first game of the season. LaFell hauled in a tough catch, where he tracked the ball after it was tipped, before being crushed by Jets safety Calvin Pryor.
Tom Brady was seen encouraging LaFell on the sideline with a slap on the back following LaFell’s sixth drop. Despite the erratic play from his receivers, Brady finished the day 34-of-54 for 355 yards and two touchdowns.
Belichick yourself before you wreck yourself
Previous -- of -- Next 10. Drew Bledsoe: It’s not Bledsoe’s fault that his injury cost him his job in 2001, but Belichick set a precedent for doing what was best for the team, regardless of prior history, when he kept Tom Brady in the starting lineup after Bledose returned. John Bohn/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next 9. Wes Welker: Belichick benched Welker for the first series of a 2011 playoff game after his snarky comments to the media leading up to the game. Jim Davis/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next 8. Expensive Cornerbacks: Ty Law, Asante Samuel, and Darrelle Revis all won Super Bowls with the Patriots (sorry Aqib Talib), but Belichick let all three go in free agency. Ezra Shaw/Getty Images, Jim Davis/Boston Globe and Steven Senne/AP Previous -- of -- Next 7. Eric Mangini: Belichick feuded with his former pupil Mangini, who left New England to become the Jets’ (and later the Browns’) head coach. Mangini ratted on the Patriots to ignite the Spygate scandal in 2007. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next 6. Fumblesome Running Backs: Laurence Maroney was benched in 2009 after a bad case of fumblitis. Stevan Ridley was relegated to the Belichick doghouse in 2013 with the same problem. Jim Davis/Boston Globe and Jamie McDonald/Getty Images Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next 5. Jonas Gray: In 2014, Gray was benched for showing up late to practice the same week he was featured on the cover of Sports Illustrated for his 201-yard, 4-TD game the week before. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next 4. Adalius Thomas: Thomas was deactivated on two occasions during the 2010 season, a season in which his play struggled, his attitude soured, and he showed up late to a practice. Pat Greenhouse/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next 3. Logan Mankins: Mankins refused to take a pay cut prior to the 2014 season, so Belichick traded him to the Buccaneers. The Bucs went 2-14, and the Patriots won the Super Bowl. AP/Brian Blanco Previous -- of -- Next 2. Richard Seymour: The Patriots shocked the world by trading Seymour prior to the 2009 season, jettisoning a defensive cornerstone Belichick didn’t anticipate being able to re-sign after the season. Matthew J. Lee/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next 1. Lawyer Milloy: Belichick outright cut the three-time All-Pro safety just five days before the 2003 season after he refused to take a pay cut. The Patriots won the next two Super Bowls. Barry Chin/Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement
